question: The nucleus of an atom is made up of which of the following combinations of particles?
To which of the following is the atomic number of a given element equivalent?
options: The number of protons in the nucleus.
The number of neutrons in the nucleus.
The sum of the protons and neutrons in the nucleus.
The number of electrons in the outer shells.

question: Rutherford's experiments involving the use of alpha particle beams directed onto thin metal foils demonstrated the existence of which of the following?
What does the mass number of a nucleus indicate?
options: The average atomic mass of the element.
The number of neutrons and protons present.

question: If there are 128 neutrons in Pb-210, how many neutrons are found in the nucleus of Pb-206?
What is the binding energy of a nucleus?
options: The energy released when nucleons bind together to form a stable nucleus.
The energy needed to remove one of the nucleons.
The average energy with which any nucleon is bound in the nucleus.
The mass of the nucleus multiplied by the square of the speed of light.

question: If the stable nuclei are plotted with neutron number versus proton number, the curve formed by the stable nuclei does not follow the line N = Z. Which of the following influences the binding energy so that this “valley of stability” forms?
options: The size of the nuclear surface.

question: As the number of protons in the nucleus increases, the repulsive force ....................
As the number of protons in the nucleus decreases, the repulsive force ....................
As the number of neutrons in the nucleus increases, the strong nuclear force ....................
As the number of neutrons in the nucleus decreases, the strong nuclear force ....................
Light nuclei are stable when the ratio of protons to neutrons is ........................
When are heavy nuclei most stable?
options: When they contain more protons than neutrons.
When they contain more neutrons than protons.
When they contain equal numbers of protons and neutrons.
When the Coulomb force is stronger than the nuclear force.

question: Of the main types of radiation emitted from naturally radioactive isotopes, which is the most penetrating?
How does a radioactive isotope that emits an alpha particle change?
A radioactive isotope that emits a beta particle change?
What are the components of natural radiation, in order from least to most penetrating?
The half-life of a certain radioactive isotope is 5 hours. How much of a 100g sample remains after 10 hours?
A 200g sample of a substance decays to 25g in 3 hours. What is the half-life?
The alpha emission process results in the daughter nucleus differing in what manner from the parent?
The beta emission process results in the daughter nucleus differing in what manner from the parent?
Samples of two different isotopes, X and Y, both contain the same number of radioactive atoms. The half-life of Sample X is twice that of Sample Y. How do their rates of radiation compare?
options: Sample X has a greater rate than sample Y.
Sample X has a smaller rate than sample Y.
The rates of Sample X and Sample Y are the same.
This can't be determined from the information given.

question: The beta emission process results in the daughter nucleus differing in what manner from the parent?
In the radioactive formula, <sup>226</sup><sub>88</sub>Ra → <sup>222</sup><sub>86</sub>Rn + X, what does X represent?
What particle is emitted when Pu-240 decays to U-236?
What particle is emitted when P-32 decays to S-32?
When Bismuth-214 emits a beta particle, the remaining daughter nucleus is ........................
Radium-226 decays to radon-222 by emitting ........................
The quotient of (0.693) divided by the half-life of a radioactive substance is equal to the ........................
How many half-lives does it take for a radioactive substance to decay to 12.5 percent of its original amount?
In order to adequately control a chain reaction, it is necessary to have within the fissionable material a non-fissionable material that ........................
Which of the following best describes nuclear fission?
options: Two light nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus.
A heavy nucleus splits into two smaller nuclei.
Electrons are ejected from a nucleus.
A nucleus emits a gamma ray.

question: Which process powers the Sun and other stars?
Which of the following is true about fusion but not about fission?
options: Can be initiated by a neutron collision.

question: In fission reactions, how must the binding energy per nucleon vary?
options: The binding energy per nucleon remains constant as atomic number increases.
The binding energy per nucleon increases as atomic number increases.
The binding energy per nucleon decreases as atomic number increases.

question: In fusion reactions, how does the binding energy per nucleon vary?
options: The binding energy per nucleon remains constant as atomic number increases.
The binding energy per nucleon remains constant as atomic number decreases.
The binding energy per nucleon increases as atomic number increases.
The binding energy per nucleon decreases as atomic number increases.

question: What daughter isotopes are produced when a neutron combines with a nucleus of <sup>235</sup><sub>92</sub>U? Assume that three neutrons are also produced in the reaction.
Why is it not possible for a thermonuclear fusion reaction to be maintained in the ocean?
options: The temperature is not high enough.
The density is not high enough.
There is insufficient deuterium in the ocean.
The deuterium in the ocean is not radioactive.

question: At this time, all nuclear reactors operate through ........................
How is a fission reactor different from a fusion reactor?
options: The transportation of fuel is safer.

question: Which statement about quarks is *not* correct?
options: Only two quarks are needed to construct a hardon.
An isolated quark has been observed by physicists.
Every quark has an antiquark of opposite charge.
There are six quarks that fit together in pairs.

question: What fuel is used in fission nuclear reactors?
Which type of radiation is emitted when uranium-238 decays to thorium-234?
In beta decay, a neutron is converted into a proton. What is emitted?
A nucleus of carbon-14 decays to nitrogen-14. What radiation is emitted?
Which decay process emits a helium nucleus?
<sup>238</sup><sub>92</sub>U → <sup>234</sup><sub>90</sub>Th + ?
<sup>14</sup>C → <sup>14</sup><sub>7</sub>N + ?
<sup>22</sup><sub>11</sub>Na → <sup>22</sup><sub>10</sub>Ne + ?
<sup>17</sup><sub>8</sub>O → <sup>17</sup><sub>9</sub>F + ?
<sup>201</sup><sub>80</sub>Hg → <sup>201</sup><sub>80</sub>Hg + ?
Which interaction of nature is weakest?
Which interaction of nature is strongest?
Which particles can mediate from the gravitational interaction?
Which particles can mediate from the weak nuclear interaction?
Which particles can mediate from the electromagnetic interaction?
Which particles can mediate from the strong nuclear interaction?
Which interaction of nature depends on the distance through which it acts and is involved in beta decay?
Which interaction of nature binds neutrons and protons into nuclei?
Which interaction of nature holds the planets, stars, and galaxies together, even though its effect on elementary particles is negligible?
Which interaction of nature binds atoms and molecules by attracting unlike charges and repulsing like charges?
Which of the following do physicists believe are fundamental particles?
Which of the following is an example of a baryon?
Which of these particles are classified as hadrons?
As the early universe cooled and expanded, which interaction separated first from the four unified interactions?
During the expansion of the early universe, which two interactions were the last to separate?
A radioactive isotope has a decay constant λ = 0.231 hr⁻¹. What is its half-life?
If a substance has a half-life of 5 days, what is the decay constant?
The decay constant of a sample is λ = 0.0693 min⁻¹. What is its half-life?
A substance has a half-life of 2 hours. What is its decay constant?
If a substance's decay constant is λ = 0.00011 day⁻¹, approximately how long is its half-life?
Which of the following is not one of the current questions regarding the standard model?
options: Why do quarks carry fractional charge and electrons carry whole charge?
How many quarks make up a proton?
